talk.author: did:plc:ko4q2nth6k46rsimakpo4jlt
talk.utter:
#threads shows one possible way.

Of course, there are always different technical approaches with advantages and disadvantages.

But none of this is a reason why I can use my #mastodon account to interact with #threads users but not with #bluesky users.

talk.author: did:plc:ko4q2nth6k46rsimakpo4jlt
talk.utter: Is your argument that if users can't port their accounts between #bluesky and #mastodon, then they're not even allowed to talk to each other?

talk.author: did:plc:ko4q2nth6k46rsimakpo4jlt
talk.utter:
I still wonder why #bluesky didn't build on #activitypub.

#bluesky, #mastodon, #threads, and countless #activitypub applications could have worked together.

Technically, that's not a problem: Everything that #bluesky was missing in #activitypub could have been easily implemented as extensions.

talk.author: did:plc:44ybard66vv44zksje25o7dz
talk.utter: did you read the post? I think both Christine and I flag significant, deep architectural differences. An ActivityPub that functioned like atproto would no longer be ActivityPub, and vice-versa.

talk.author: did:plc:44ybard66vv44zksje25o7dz
talk.utter: extensions are cool, but if there isn't interop what is the point? eg, if we had added nomadic identity and data transfer, but Mastodon (the software project) never implemented their side, what would have been the point?

talk.author: did:plc:ko4q2nth6k46rsimakpo4jlt
talk.utter: Well, #atproto is cool, but since there is no interop what is the point? eg nobody else implemented their side, so what is the point?ðŸ˜‰

talk.author: did:plc:ko4q2nth6k46rsimakpo4jlt
talk.utter:
The point is: 

If #bluesky was built on top of #activitypub (even if #mastodon didn't implement #bluesky-#activitypub extensions), then this would have enabled significant interaction between #bluesky, #mastodon and #threads. 

Wouldn't that have been cool?

What speaks against it?

talk.author: did:plc:ko4q2nth6k46rsimakpo4jlt
talk.utter: Well, #atproto is cool, but since there is no interop what is the point? eg nobody else implemented their side, so what is the point?ðŸ˜‰

talk.author: did:plc:ko4q2nth6k46rsimakpo4jlt
talk.utter:
The point is: 

If #bluesky was built on top of #activitypub (even if #mastodon didn't implement #bluesky-#activitypub extensions), then this would have enabled significant interaction between #bluesky, #mastodon and #threads. 

Wouldn't that have been cool?

What speaks against it?

talk.author: did:plc:44ybard66vv44zksje25o7dz
talk.utter:
I'm not really sure what you mean: a ton of folks have implemented interoperable systems with atproto. feed generators, PDS implementations, labelers, etc.

if you want just any degree of interop with mastodon, doesn't bridgy fed work?

talk.author: did:plc:44ybard66vv44zksje25o7dz
talk.utter: what we don't want is Threads <=> Mastodon style interop: some messages get passed "natively", but you can't actually migrate accounts and "exit"

talk.author: did:plc:ko4q2nth6k46rsimakpo4jlt
talk.utter:
Which of the "ton of [...] interoperable systems with atproto" can the people from #mastodon, #bluesky and #threads all interact with together?

Bridgy doesn't work in practice, because it's opt-in.

If you don't want "Threads <=> Mastodon style interop", then of course this goal is achieved.ðŸ˜‰
